item.def: Out of existence. Only in to do (also bring) (a person) adawe: to put (a person) to death; to do away with, kill
Single, singular, sole, only. Obs.
Back; wenden on ~, pervert
Obs. (Eng. regional (north.) in later use). trans. To know, recognize; to come to know, understand.
A draught-horse, a cart-horse: an old horse or one of little value
Bearing, demeanour
Within
To accuse of a heinous crime whereby the accuser has received personal injury or wrong, for which he demands reparation
intr. Of persons: To defend; to come, go, or get down; to dismount, alight
A draught-horse, a cart-horse: an old horse or one of little value
trans. To punish or take vengeance upon (an offence, misdeed)
A stream or its valley; vale, dale, hollow; cou ~, cow pasture
In one body or company, together
1. A ring or torque of metal, usually meant for the arm or neck; but in one case at least used of a finger-ring. Obs.

1. a. An implement consisting of a heavy weight or ‘head,’ usually of wood, with a handle or stock, used for driving wedges or pegs, ramming down paving stones, or for crushing, bruising, beating, flattening, or smoothing, in various industrial and domestic operations, and having various shapes according to the purpose for which it is used; a mall
pa.t. of begin, also used as pa.p. Gen.Sc. for Eng. began
To promise
2. refl. To lament or bewail one’s lot
2. (a) Soldier; esp., a knight; ~ of armes, man-at-arms; breneid ~, a mailed warrior; (b) a nobleman, a lord; — often equated with baroun baron
Obs. 1. a. A box, a casket; chiefly used of a box for ointment, a vase or flask for oil, etc. (= BOX n.2 1.)
Obs. exc. poet. and dial. (brim) in sense A. 6. A. adj. I. Celebrated, brilliant, clear, loud, distinct
prop. A plant (Stachys betonica) of the Labiate order, having spiked purple flowers and ovate crenate leaves. In former days medicinal and magical virtues were attributed to it
To happen, occur, befall. Freq. with person as indirect object. (In Old English with dative of person). Also with to.
Obs. 1. trans. To mean, signify, import; 2. Obs. rare. intr. To mediate, intercede
With speed, with haste, quickly, eagerly
fig. To encompass, surround, assail, possess detrimentally: a. said of temptations, dangers, difficulties, obstacles, evil influences
trans. To spit upon, cover or defile with spitting. Rarely intr. with upon. (Cf. BESPETE v.)
A means of help or succour
A weapon of war mentioned in Old English poetry, a kind of broadsword, a falchion
Within, inside of; in, into
transf. A young man, youngster, child, son

[OE ge)byrian, & cp. OI byrja. In ME this verb, a synonym of bihoōven, occurs almost exclusively in the NM and the N, and only in the 3rd person.] 1b. With personal subj.: (a) to be under obligation, be in duty bound (to do sth.), ought (to do)
To trick or delude (sb.), as by witchcraft, cunning, or insincerity.
Obs. intr. To turn pale
To serve (a cow) with a bull
Swelling, state of being swollen; concr. a swelling, a tumour
Chem. A globular flask with a long cylindrical neck, used in distillation
Obs. or dial. A. adv.1 Outside, without; out
3. (a) To tear or cut (sb.) to pieces; rend, slash; slay; ~ to dethe, ~ to noȝt, kill; destroy (the soul); (b) to go to pieces, be annihilated
=BUSH: A woods, grove; thicket, underbrush; bank and ~, hill and (wooded) dale; under the ~, in (the shelter of) the woods; (b) rank growth
Now rare (Sc., Irish English, and Eng. regional (north.) in later use). I. To prepare, and related senses. 1. a. trans. (refl.). To prepare or equip oneself; to make oneself ready.
BOUT adv., Outside, without; out; prep., Outside of, without
A long, white night-shirt
Clent Hills, south of Birmingham, where Kenhelm was murdered
To know. Obs. = CAN v.1 1 – 2 (pa. tense and pple. rarely cunde, conde.)
†1. a. A living body; = CORPSE n. 1. Obs.
To immerse as a religious rite, to baptize

To injure (sb.), wrong, kill; damage (sth.), destroy; oppress (people, a country); afflict, torment, torture; ~ abrod, to scatter (an army) in defeat; (b) to disturb (sb.), trouble, annoy; grieve (sb.), frighten; of care, disease, love, sin, etc.: distress (sb.); (c) to lower (oneself), debase; (d) to delude (sb.), fool; (e) to speculate, ?worry about something
2. a. To endure, undergo, suffer, bear (something burdensome, grievous, or painful)
Turbid; clouded
Darling, love, friend
Grief, sorrow, mental distress
Happy, fortunate, well-omened. Also, Blessed, saintly; said of persons and their actions
=EGG
Only in phrase, this ender day, night, year, indicating a day, etc. recently past
A troubled state of mind, grief, vexation; also concr. a cause of trouble
= ENVIRON v. 1. trans. a. To form a ring round, surround, encircle
The land where one dwells; native land, home; a region, country
That cannot be terminated; without termination or end; eternal
Easily, without difficulty
? Valiant
Obs. trans. To hasten, hurry; also refl.
Obs. A messenger, ambassador
1. Of a pale brownish or reddish yellow colour, as withered grass or leaves. Obs. exc. of the coat of an animal; now chiefly in FALLOW-DEER n.
In predicative use: Much, many, numerous. Also in compar.: More in number, more numerous
A companion, comrade, mate, partner; whether male or female
3. An equal. a. Of a person: Peer; also in phrase, without (peer or) fere
3a. Strange, wonderful, wondrous, marvellous
intr. To wonder
In early use = FISTULA n.; subsequently, a rankling sore, an ulcer. In mod. use: ‘A superficial suppuration resulting from irritation of the skin’ (Quain Dict. Med. 1882)
Obs. 1.a. The surface of the earth; the ground
trans. To put to the proof, try, test (a person or thing); to make trial of (one’s strength, skill); to taste (food, etc.); in early use with gen.
4.a. To set or establish (something immaterial) on a firm basis; to give a basis or firm support to
Obs. Chiefly north. Full of force, powerful, strong
Obs. 1. trans. To try, put to the proof, test
†1. = BROTHER n., in fig. applications; esp. in Old French phrase beu frere ‘fair brother’. Obs.
With uncertain meaning, denoting a wood of some kind, or wooded country collectively, esp. in poet. phrases associated with fell, field
Entertainment as a guest, lodging, hospitality. Also, a banquet, feast.
Foolish, simple
A testicle; pl. the testicles, but in later use = genitals. (Cf. GENITURE n.)
2. Carefully, exactly; properly; quite, really; well
trans. To make ready, prepare, put in order, repair; also, to procure
A cry; outcry; noise
Cruel, painful, bitter, severe, terrible, dreadful
a. The action of the verb GRUTCH v.; murmuring, complaining; murmur, complaint, reluctance
[Imitative or fanciful.] a. An imitative sound or mocking term
a. A cry of anger or chiding addressed to a horse
A halo
A corner, recess, hiding-place
reward〈OE hanse

An officer of a manor, township, or parish, having charge of the fences and enclosures, esp. to keep cattle from breaking through from the common into enclosed fields; sometimes, the herdsman of the cattle feeding on the common
Sc. Obs. 1. trans. To cover; to shield, protect; to hide
(a) A poor man; (b) a rascal; ?a niggard; (c) as personal name
= HENCE adv. : of place, time, or inference
Near, at hand
trans. To praise, glorify, exalt, honour, worship
(a) A secret place, hiding place; refuge; also, a hollow in a stalk of grain; (b) in (on) ~, in secrecy, in private, secretly; putten into ~, to conceal (sb.); (c) ~ place, hidden place
Obs. Winter; esp. in poet. personification

A. adj.1 1. Situated behind, at the back, or in the rear; posterior. (Notwithstanding its comparative form, it does not differ in sense from hind, but is more frequently used. Cf. YON adv., YONDER adv., adj., pron., and n.) hinder gate, postern gate. 2. Of time. a. Last past, ‘last’; as in this hinder day yesterday, this hinder night last night, yesternight.
Obs. Dirt, filth, defilement, foulness

(a) To defile (sb. or sth.), defoul, pollute; (b) to be or become physically corrupted or rancid; also fig. [quot.: c1390]; (c) ppl. horied, of a person: defiled, corrupted; of an animal: ceremonially unclean.
adj., Situated behind, at the back, or in the rear; posterior. (Notwithstanding its comparative form, it does not differ in sense from hind, but is more frequently used)
trans. To take up (water, etc.) with a shallow vessel; to scoop up, ladle out: = CLEACH v. 3
Known
= kingdom n., in various senses
Obs. exc. dial. †1. A male child, a boy (= KNAVE n. 1); a lad, young man, youth, fellow. Obs
2. An official who has charge of a larder
Sport, entertainment [ON leikr]
Law; esp. religious law; hence, a religion, a faith
Loyally, faithfully, truly
trans. and intr. To glean. †Also with up. (In Old English used in wider sense: to gather, collect.)
Obs. 3. a. sing. A man, person; esp. one of the ‘men’ or subjects of a king or chief; a subject. Also poet. in Old English, a king
Spring; = LENT noun 1
Now Sc. and north. dial. Light, flame; a flash, ray, or gleam of light; brightness, gleam
To arrive, come. Also refl.
A people, nation, race. Also, persons collectively, ‘people’
The body; the living body; also, the body as the seat of desire and appetite
Tranquillity, peace, rest; joy, delight
Obs. A calm, lull; fig. respite
To hearken, listen. Const. dat., or to, unto (at, till). Also, to hear of (a thing)
Of persons, their actions, dispositions, etc.: Bad, wicked; base, rascally unjust
Praise; renown, fame. Also in neutral sense, (good or bad) reputation
A supporter, helper; (b) a supporter of evil or of evil-doers; ? = maintenour 1. (maintainer)
(a) A mingling, an intermixture; confusion
The song thrush, Turdus philomelos. Also in extended use. Now poet. and Brit. regional
Recompense, reparation; penance
Worshipful, honourable; gracious, beautiful. Of a building: stately
I. Senses relating to memory. 1. The state of being remembered; remembrance, recollection. Chiefly in phrases
(a) Mouth; maugre his ~, in spite of himself; ~ pin, a tooth; (b) mouth of a river, only in place names [see Smith PNElem. 2.45]; (c)?as surname
(a) A rawhide shoe or boot; (b) as a derogatory nickname for a Scot
(a) The kidney of a human being or animal
= NIGHT
Now arch. and hist. 1. A coward, a villain; a person who breaks the law or a code of honour; an outlaw. †2. A mean or niggardly person; a miser. Obs.
Causing annoyance; vexatious, troublesome; (also) †causing harm or injury (obs.)
Usu. derogatory. Obs. Chiefly Sc. in later use. The lending of money at (excessive) interest, usury; interest gained from this
Strong feeling against a person, animus; spite, hatred, envy. In early use also: fear, terror
Mercy, pardon, forgiveness; source of pardon
Chiefly Sc. Obs. To adorn richly all over. Chiefly in pass. Also fig.
Immoderate; excessive; presumptuous

Originally: designating a county or other territory in England (and later other countries) as having a ruler with royal privileges and judicial authority (within the territory) which elsewhere belong to the sovereign alone (now hist.). Later: designating a modern administrative area corresponding to this
Easter; (formerly also) †Passover (obs.); = PASCH n.
Satisfaction, pleasure, liking. Obs.
trans. To make peace between or reconcile (two or more persons); to reconcile (one person) with another
A payment or wages in advance; money paid on account to enable a person to proceed with an undertaking

To deprive (sb.) of (sth.), deny (sb. sth.); ppl. prived, bereaved, bereft of, deprived of; without; (b) ~ of (from), to deprive (sb. of sth.), deny (sth. to sb.), exclude (sb. from sth.); prived of (from), deprived of (sth.), bereft of; lacking, without; ben of god priving, be a robber of goods; (c) to depose (sb.), dismiss; ~ of (from), deprive (sb.) of (power, kingdom, etc.), remove or dismiss (sb.) from (office or position); (d) to take (sth.) away; prevent (sth.), deny, oppose; weaken (the body); -- also without obj.
That has been made pure
Obs. A. n. 1. Dung, excrement, filth; 2. Evil, wickedness; mischief; harm. Also: an evil thing, an evil deed
To placate, appease (a person, esp. God). Obs.
(a) ?A line of dancers
a. lit. and fig. A (rapid) turn, revolution or rotatory motion, as of a wheel; b. A swift or violent whirling motion, as of wind or water
intr. To stretch oneself, esp. on waking from sleep or as a preliminary to further action; to rouse, stir oneself. Also: to yawn (obs.)
trans. To tear; to split, cleave
Of the mind or its powers, esp. memory: Undiminished; not weakened by the passage of time; in full vigour
Obs. Resplendent; brilliant
Obs. Sorrow, penitence, repentance; an instance of this. Also: pity; mercy
Now chiefly Brit. regional and Irish English (north.). 1. collect. Twigs or small branches growing on trees or bushes; dense growth of bushes; brushwood, thicket. Now Sc. (chiefly Orkney) and rare
A robber, a plunderer, a looter
trans. To count, reckon, enumerate. Also occas. intr. Now only with up. Formerly also: †to recount (obs.)
The bank of a river
(a) A rawhide shoe or boot; (b) as a derogatory nickname for a Scot
A distaff. Occas. also: a spindle
Obs. A short poem or song, esp. a love song
Obs. 1. a. The action of sending; that which is sent, a message, present; (God’s) dispensation or ordinance
Formerly Tsarev; now New Sarai, Mongolia.
Obs. (since 14th c. only Sc. and north.). 1. An agreement, covenant; 2. Agreement, freedom from strife, peace
Not allowed to be revealed, hidden, occult
Happy, blissful; fortunate, lucky, well-omened, auspicious
B. adv. Wonderfully, marvellously, strangely
Appearance, ‘false semblant’
2. Seeing or considering (that)
B. 2. Divers, various, sundry
In Old English, a table or counter for exposing goods for sale, counting money, etc. Obs.

[Aberrant form of chevale macronr n., perh. influenced by a local var. or surname in the north of England, which may also have produced AL schavaldor.] A wanderer, vagabond; also, a gentleman robber near the Scottish border; ?also, a minstrel or entertainer; (b) as surname
The Thursday in Holy Week, Maundy Thursday
A. Sonorous, resonant, shrill
Obs. exc. dial. 1. Relationship, kinship, consanguinity
Free from danger or harm; secure, safe

A loaf or bun made of fine flour, usu. lighter than wastel; bread of this kind; ~ horn, ~ with the horn, ?a loaf of this bread made with pointed ends or corners; ferthing ~, a loaf of this bread worth one farthing; (b) ~ silver, ?money paid for transporting bread of this kind; (c) in surnames

Obs.1. A going, journey, path, way.This sense is very common in Old English poetry; 2.a. Fortune on a journey; also generally, fortune, hap, luck; 3. One’s pilgrimage on earth; life-time; the course of one’s life
†2. Prudence; wisdom, knowledge. Obs.
Various parts of a pig or other animal, esp. the feet and ears, prepared or preserved for food by means of pickling

(a) To save, hoard; save (sth.), refrain from using or consuming; ~ stounde, fail to use (an opportunity); ~ wrecche men, save (sth.) for the poor; (b) to refrain from inflicting injury or punishment (on sb.); spare (sb.) pain or suffering; save (sb. from death or pain); also, give (sb.) respite or reprieve; ~ to, spare (sb. from sins); (c) to relieve (a disagreeable situation)
? To keep back (the truth). Obs.
Now only Sc. a. = STAR n.1
trans. To stun as with a blow; to stupefy, benumb; to stupefy with astonishment, bewilder
intr. To ascend, mount up, rise or climb to a higher level. Said of persons and things
1. a roast of pork
Cookery. To beat up, ‘whip’ (milk, eggs, etc.). Obs.
Directly or next after that; at the next moment; immediately afterwards; then, thereupon; = SINCE adv. 1
A spot, blotch, blot
A piece of figured cloth used as a hanging, table-cover, carpet, or the like
Attention, heed, care; nearly always in the phrases give tent, to give heed, pay attention (obs.), and take tent, to take heed, take care; with to, to pay attention to, take heed to
Obs. Dark. lit. and fig.
Qualifying a plural noun or singular nouns indicating something physically present or near or something which has already been or is about to be mentioned: THESE
Patiently, submissively, meekly
b. The finest fibre of flax or hemp
[?] A drinking vessel of some sort. — Len me thy batty towt [Ch. that batye tout]
Obs. An expression of contempt
Sc. and north. Obs. 1. trans. To make secure or safe, to commit in trust; hence refl. to commit oneself with security or confidence, to trust, = sense 2
Obs. 1. trans. To cause to roll or revolve; to roll: = TRUNDLE v. 1a.
A deceiver, a cheat
A dining room
Sc. Obs. Undisciplined
Unfortunate, unhappy, miserable, wretched; deserving pity
Rising from the dead; resurrection
in ure: In or into use, practice, or performance. Often with vbs., as bring, come, have, and esp. put (freq. c1510–1630)
The season of spring; springtime
An adulterer
a paragon of beauty or excellence, someone chosen for virtue
Misery, distress, hardship; adversity, poverty
Obs. exc. dial. †1. The cheek. Obs.
A wilderness
gen. A track prepared or available for travelling along; a road, street, lane, or path
In indefinite usages, often in statements relating to the human condition generally: (2a) we, one, people, everybody; also used conventionally in prayers, carols, etc.
Obs. exc. arch. 1. trans. In regard to what is present or past: To think, surmise, suppose, conceive, believe, consider. In Middle English often with well

1. Warfare. a. A state or period of hostilities and combat existing between political groups, esp. realms or nations; also, specif. the warlike activity appropriate to knights, and also sometimes applied to the skills involved (see (3) below and cf. some quots. in 2 (1)). b. Hostilities, strife, etc. between (groups of) individuals pursuing private enmities.
†1. A cloud. Obs.
Obs. A. n. The condition of being exposed to or liable to injury or harm; danger, peril; hurt or harm; a cause of harm or injury
Retributive punishment; vengeance; = WREAK n. 1.
Vengeful; revengeful.
unfortunately, disastrously. Cf. HAIL n.2 2, hale n.1 b.
(attrib. or adj.) Of a horse: Worn out
intr. To boast, speak vaingloriously
Obs. trans. (in Old English const. gen. or dat.) and intr. To covet [fom which: yissing n. coveting, covetousness]
